choices.C: Grant unlimited tablespace privilege to the database user.
choices.A: Create a database user account for the business analyst.
choices.B: Grant the predefined database role DWROLE to the database user.
choices.D: Grant the predefined database role DWADW to the database user.
choices.E: Grant the predefined database role DWUSER to the database user.

discussion.content:
AB is a better choice. The requirement doesn't state that the analyst needs to upload data (for him to receive unlimited tablespace) but it would be a fair assumption that we need to create a user for him.
https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/autonomous-data-warehouse-cloud/user/manage-users-privileges.html#GUID-50450FAD-9769-4CF7-B0D1-EC14B465B873
LMAO!! C!?? unlimited tablespace to run queries???

Should be A & B. Granting unlimited tablespace is not wrong but this requirement was not spelled out hence it's not mandatory as opposed to A & B which is the fundamental steps to fulfil the needs as stated in the question
A and B!!

comments.content: Give UNLIMITED TABLESPACE permission to a user is not a good idea. It's a permission thought for admins only. Users should be given quotas on pertinent tablespaces
is the exam quetions accurate . I have a week only so was relaing on this dump

Moreover, the questions says the user has only to run queries, so he/she doesn't need to be given any quota, as quota are only used for DML (INSERT, DELETE, UPDATE, MERGE) or DCL (CREATE, DROP, ALTER segments)

discussion.content:
Going with the 
https://docs.oracle.com/en/cloud/paas/autonomous-data-warehouse-cloud/user/manage-users-privileges.html#GUID-50450FAD-9769-4CF7-B0D1-EC14B465B873
B & C is the right ..
Creating user should be outside the scope
a and B

A & B are the most adequate solutions. there are no roles called DWADW or DWUSER in autonomous DB, and there is no need to grant unlimited tablespace as the user will not create any tables and will just query the data. at the end A and B are 2 complementary steps you need firstly to create user and then grant him access
I think it is A B

Autonomous Data Warehouse databases come with a predefined database role named DWROLE. This role provides the privileges necessary for most database users. Here are the privileges it grants a user:
A and B are correct

questions.question_text:
You provisioned an Oracle Autonomous Data Warehouse (ADW) on Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) and imported data into ADW.
You want to give your business analyst the ability to connect to the ADW database and run queries.
Which two actions can help you meet this requirement? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
B is correct. Cross tenancy VCNs can be peered.
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Tasks/localVCNpeering.htm

Only B is correct.
C is not right - we can peer with any VCN outside tenancy as well
answer is B

B and C both are true
Two VCNs with non-overlapping CIDRs, in different regions that support remote peering. The VCNs must be in the same tenancy.

comments.content: You can do local peering between tenancies

discussion.content:
I agree, the correct answer is B.
C is not correct, you can peer networks from different tenancies.

The VCNs can be in the same Oracle Cloud Infrastructure tenancy or different ones. Without peering, a given VCN would need an internet gateway and public IP addresses for the instances that need to communicate with another VCN. https://docs.cloud.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Network/Tasks/localVCNpeering.htm
B. is correct

Both B & C are correct..
difficult to pick one

choices.D: The only way to interconnect VCNs is through peering.
choices.B: Peering VCNs should not have overlapping CIDR blocks.
choices.C: VCNs must be in the same tenancy to be peered.

choices.E: You can only restore a volume to the same availability domain in which the original block volume resides.
choices.C: You can restore a volume from any full volume backup but not from an incremental backup.
